title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
background: The vestibular system receives permanent influence from gravity and reflexively controls equilibrium. This study investigates whether sensory systems adapt to abrupt loss of gravitational force during spaceflight, using land snails as a model organism.
objective: To identify adaptive changes in the vestibular system at behavioral, structural, molecular, and neurophysiological levels following 30-day spaceflight exposure and subsequent readaptation to Earth gravity.
methods: Land snails (Helix lucorum) were exposed to 30 days of microgravity aboard Bion-M1 satellite. Postflight analysis included geotactic behavior assessment, statocyst transcriptome analysis via RNA-Seq, SEM imaging of statoconia, and electrophysiological recordings of mechanoreceptor responses to tilt stimuli. Multiple control groups accounted for habitat factors.
results: Spaceflight induced plastic changes in the snail vestibular system: postflight snails showed shortened T0 phase latency in gravitaxis, reduced tentacle withdrawal, and increased statocyst sensitivity to tilt stimuli. Transcriptome analysis revealed 3,544 differentially expressed genes. Readaptation to normal tilt responses occurred at ~20 hours post-landing. No changes in statoconia mass or structure were detected.
conclusion: Despite gravity's evolutionary permanence, the snail vestibular system demonstrates compensatory plasticity to microgravity exposure and rapid readaptation upon return to Earth gravity, providing insights into neural adaptation mechanisms relevant to spaceflight.

learning_notes.note: Land snails exposed to 30 days of microgravity aboard Bion-M1 satellite showed significant behavioral changes in gravitaxis, including shortened T0 phase latency (8-15 seconds in controls vs. significantly shorter in postflight) and reduced tentacle withdrawal during the initial fear response phase, indicating altered vestibular-mediated behavior.

Electrophysiological recordings revealed postflight hypersensitivity in statocyst responses to tilt stimuli, with PF snails showing 80.4Â±4.44 spikes vs. 52.58-68.68 in controls for head-down tilt, suggesting neural plasticity rather than structural changes as the adaptation mechanism.

Transcriptome analysis identified 3,544 differentially expressed genes in statocysts between postflight and control groups, including neuronal precursors of neuropeptides and neurotransmitter receptor subunits, confirming the statocyst as the site of neural plasticity during readaptation.

The critical readaptation period to Earth gravity was approximately 20 hours post-landing, with statocyst responses significantly larger in early recordings (<20 hours) compared to late recordings (>20 hours), similar to recovery timelines observed in vertebrate studies and astronauts.

No structural changes were detected in statoconia mass or surface structure via SEM imaging despite 30-day microgravity exposure, contradicting previous studies that suggested statoconia growth as an adaptation mechanism, possibly due to differences in snail age/species.

Single unit analysis revealed that directional sensitivity to head-down tilt is maintained postflight and primarily mediated by an unpaired sensory neuron at the anterior pole of the statocyst, demonstrating preservation of fundamental spatial orientation capabilities despite adaptation.

Comparison between 12-day (Foton-M3) and 30-day (Bion-M1) missions showed no significant difference in adaptation magnitude, suggesting vestibular sensitivity changes reach a plateau within 12 days of microgravity exposure, important for understanding adaptation timelines.
